answer: Patience is when you're waiting. I was patient when in line waiting for lunch. I didn't cut anyone to eat. I was standing and waiting for my turn, just like everyone else. Patience, some people don't have it. Lots of people just cut or yell at you because they don't have any patience. Sometimes people will push you out of their way to get ahead. They only do that because they don't have patience at all and only think about themselves. Patience is what people need. People need patience because lots of feelings get hurt when people are inconsiderate. Everyone should have patience to make the world a kinder place.

I am not a patient person, like I can't sit still for more than five minutes, but there was one time I was patient, and I bet everyone else was too: learning to ride a bike without training wheels. When I was five, I learned how to ride a bike; I just kept falling off. At one point, my bike flipped, and I almost broke my jaw, but I didn't. Finally, after two weeks of constant falling, I rode for five minutes without falling and finally learned how to ride a bike, proving that even the most impatient people can find patience when learning something new.

One day I was at basketball practice and I was running hard with my team when I was getting really, really thirsty. After we did our suicides, I asked coach if we could go get some drinks. Coach said, "After our double dribble down and back exercise." I did the exercise, and we all rushed to the drinking fountain, and I was at the end of a long girl's line. I waited and waited until finally there I was, faced with that drinking fountain, when one girl says, "Can I have a drink, thank you?" and all I could do was be stunned. That's when I heard a bright "Ladies, let's go!" I was mad, but I quickly took a short, two-second drink of water and rushed over to coach, and now I'm the first one a lot, and I take long drinks, so my teammates call me a fish! This nickname, though born from frustration, now just makes me laugh.

I going to write about a time when I went to the @ORGANIZATION1 fair, we had fun, we saw a ride we wanted to get on, so we got in line. Suddenly, we noticed that we were at the end of the line. So my mother said, “@CAPS1 get on another ride then.” “We already tried the other rides,” my father said. So we stayed at the end of the line until it was our turn, and said that was the last ride. Soon there were people behind us complaining, their younger children were getting mad, and parents were hollering. We just stood there, and kept being patient. That didn’t disturb us, since we were raised to be patient, and wait our turn at things. I feel being patient is very important, because if you act up in line, you might make people think they’re holding you up, but it’s the line moving slow. Advice: when you are waiting at the end of the line, don’t shout, scream, holler, or yell at anyone, it only creates trouble. Just don’t think about all of the people ahead of you, talk to someone, just take your mind off of it for a while, then you’ll notice, the line is moving quicker than you expected. Therefore, patience is a virtue worth cultivating, especially in situations that test our limits, because maintaining composure not only benefits ourselves but also contributes to a more pleasant environment for everyone. P.S. We enjoyed the ride.

There was a girl name Lily. She loved spending time with her mom. Every weekend they would either go to the movies, amusement or water park, or just stay home. This time was different though. Lily was even a little scared about what was about to happen. Today was a Sunday and Lily and her mom was watching videos of her mom when she was young. After the video, Lily and her mom looked at each other and laughed. Once they settled down, Lily’s mom looked sad. “What’s wrong mom?” Lily asked. “I have to go. I have to go somewhere for work and can’t take you with me,” mom replied. “Why not?” asked Lily. “I don’t know, but I need you to wait here with your father. I’ll be back soon,” the mom said calmly. With that Lily’s mom left and drove away. Lily stood there confused and wishing her mom didn’t have to go. Then she went to the phone and called her dad. An hour later, Lily’s dad came to her house. He calmed Lily down, who had been crying because she missed her mom. Lily went to her room and began to wait patiently for her mom. Weeks past and Lily’s mom still hasn’t returned. Every night now Lily cried hoping her mom would come. During the day she would wait watching for her mom. Lily wanted her mom more than ever now. Though see never complained to her father and understands that her mom left for an important reason, but still she missed her mom. Two years have passed since Lily’s mom had left. Lily didn’t cry as much but still waited. Waited for her mother to come back. One day Lily heard a knock on the door, she answered it and there stood her mother. They stood on the porch for a moment, then hugged each other tightly. They both cried and her mom whispered “I’m sorry,” to Lily. Now Lily and her were unseperatable. They never left each other’s side again, cherishing every moment together after their long separation.

If you could ask for one thing, would you ask for patients or motivation? In this situation I would ask for patients. I remember when I was about four or five years old. My two sisters and I boarded a plane to Florida. It seemed like we were sitting on the plane for hours before it actually took off. After about ten minutes, I asked if we would be there soon. My sister said no, and that we were only up in the air for about ten minutes. I watched all the people just sitting there; some were on laptops and listening to MP3 players. I looked up at my sister and wondered how she could be so patient. After I asked if we were almost there for the second time, my sister did not answer me. I just sat there doing nothing. I had nothing to entertain myself with. I did not say a word for two hours then I eventually fell asleep. If you could ask for one thing, would you ask for patients or motivation? I am still not very patient, but I am more patient than I was back then, and I believe that patience, unlike fleeting motivation, provides a more stable foundation for navigating life's inevitable delays and challenges.

“Look out!” Mom squealed. The sound of crunching metal was deafening. There was no way out. My eyes seemed sealed shut, but they were as wide as could be. The eerie silence frightened me. I felt arms grab me, pulling me to what they considered safety. In no way, was this to be considered safety, for this was the beginning of one living-nightmare. The living nightmare of my life. Here’s a picture of what I saw: mangled cars, twisted, tangled and smushed so close together, they seemed as if they were one object. Lying beside me was a small boy. That boy was my brother, Timmy. His chest expands slowly, but as it does, excruciating sounds radiate from him. Blood trickles out from his many cuts. It’s unbearable to watch. Ambulances’ sirens wail as they approach. My father I have yet to see. And that’s what scares me most. I still have nightmares of that night. The night everything changed. Not only had I lost my father and brother, but in someways, I’d lost my mother as well. I’d never understand the pain of watching your little brother die, all because of something you desired. If I hadn’t made my father turn around to get my forgotten notebook, I’d still have a father and little Timmy. Ever since the funeral, I could feel my mother and I pulling apart. Nothing with us has been the same since. We fight constantly, never listening to what the other has to say. Maybe it’s just the life of a typical teen and her mother. I wouldn’t know because in no way we we typical. When we aren’t fighting about who- knows-what, we just keep our distance. Sometimes, though, the silence is scarier, more heart pounding, than the shouting. Silence is just so freaking loud! My mother is beginning to attempt the seemingly impossible. She begins to try and understand my strange ways. “Honey,” she starts, “I know I haven’t been patient with you lately, and for that I’m sorry. I will try to be, starting now. I only ask you of one thing.” I give her a questioning, gaze, so she continues, “I would like you to tell me why you blame yourself?” She didn’t have to explain any farther. “Mom, I made Dad turn around,” my voice caught in my throat, “just to get my stupid notebook.” A single tear weaved its way down my face. “Sweetheart, hunny!” my mother teared up as well. “That doesn’t make it your fault! You had no idea it would end that way!” I knew my patience had been worn through for a long time, but I refused to snap at my mother now. She was only trying to help. I fought my annoyed tone, which was battling its way out. But I was to win that fight. “Mom,” I said, regaining composure, “that’s how I feel about the issue. I wish I could just take your word for it, and maybe overtime I will, but right now, I just need my space.” What shocked me most was the smile that formed on my mother’s lips. “I will wait then.” And then she hugged me. She hugged me as she had when I was four and broke my leg. Tight and unhesitantly. I could feel the beginning of a new found relationship with my mother. Maybe not as strong as it had been, but definitely there. With patience and time, it has bloomed into a healthy relationship, in which we both can enjoy and respect, showing how even after immense tragedy, healing and reconnection are possible through understanding and patience.

There once was a soldier named Connor. He is a private first class. His bestfriend named Dave, he was also a private. “I can’t believe we have to wait six months before we actually get to deploy,” Connor said with a sigh. “That’s how it is, man,” Dave replied, patting him on the back. They were walking to the firing range. Ping! Went the target as the bullet struck it. “Nice shot!,” said Dave impressed. “Thanks,” Connor replied humbly. Right in the center was the hole were the bullet struck. Connor had great aim but he still had to wait. “Patience,” Dave said knowingly. Connor was patient and all but he wanted to go so bad. Finally his time came, deployment. He was so excited to go. One day on patrol his convoy was hit hard by mortars, he was killed in an instant. In this story patience is the key to everything; remember about patience next time you have to wait. It is a virtue that can help us navigate the inevitable delays and disappointments in life, even when faced with the ultimate sacrifice.

The whole point is that being patient is important in life, allowing things to proceed smoothly without unnecessary stress or conflict.

Have you ever waited for something or someone without complaining? If so, you are being patient. Patience isn’t just waiting a long time, it’s being respectful and not complaining about waiting. Hi, I'm writing about the topic of patience. I think patience is very important to the world. Because if no one had patience everyone would be running crazy like banshees and getting mad all the time. It is important to have patience because in life it's not always fair and you have to wait your turn. For example, when I go to get my allergy shots I have to be patient because other people got there first and have to get served first. I also have to be patient at my football games because everyone has to play, and I can't play in one spot the whole game. Lots of people that aren't patient make other people not patient. Another term for not patient is impatient. Everyone needs to have some sort of patience; it makes things run smoother. That is what this world needs, a little more patience, to make things a little easier for everyone.

Patience is a virtue. It’s something that we all need in life. Without it we can’t do anything that requires patience. People would get bored because they have no patience. Now, here’s a time I was patient. After my birthday, I decided to buy an iPod touch. Since no stores were open, I had only one other option: online shopping. I used Amazon to get it. I couldn’t wait to get it! Unfortunately, I had to wait like a week to get it. It was boring waiting for it, but I had other things to occupy my mind. When it finally came, I was so happy! I was glad I waited. From that experience with patience, I learned you can’t get everything right away, and I learned that for people who wait, good things will come to them. Also, I was better at waiting for everything. That’s how I was patient and have been better at being patient ever since then.

Patience is very important in life. I have been patient many times in days. I'm going to tell you about a time that I was patient and it paid off. It was July 25th, exactly two months before my birthday. I went to my mom and asked her if I could get a phone. She said I was too young, and that she didn't get a phone till she was in college. I told her that everyone else had a cell phone but me, this was partly true. She told me she would think about it, and that if I bugged her about it again she wouldn't get me a phone. It was September 20th now, just five more days till my birthday. I thought about what kind of phone I wanted, I thought about what color case I would get for it. I thought about that phone for weeks. Then the day came, it was September 25th, my birthday. I woke up in the morning to the smell of pancakes. After we ate we went to my grandma's house, because it was also Thanksgiving. After dinner we went back to my house for my birthday surprise. I opened my presents from aunts, uncles, grandparents, and then the last box. I opened it, it was my phone! I was so excited, I called all my friends on my new phone. That was the best birthday ever. It is a good thing to be patient, because I was patient I got the phone I wanted. That's why you should always be patient, and wait, because sometimes the things you want most come to you when you least expect it. By; Alex.

Patience is something that people don't have sometimes. I know I did once. And I 'm gonna tell you about it. It was a bright sunny day. All my family members were outside. All of us knew how to throw and catch a football but not my little brother. Considering the fact that all of us were chose to teach my little brother. We tried once, we tried twice, but he just wouldn't get the hang of it. Finally all my sisters got tired of explaining him the object of the game, so they gave up. Me, on the other side said it over and over until he understood it. I myself got tired of telling him over and what to do. But then I thought 'hey give the kid a chance he might just get it 'so I just kept on helping him. "Food is ready! Come inside", my mom had called out. "Time for food lets go inside" I said to my little brother. "Please! Just one last time, I promise I will get it!" he exclaimed. "Alright, but just one time" I responded. Even tho he had been saying that the past few hundred times he'd tried, I thought it wouldn't hurt to do it once more. As I released the ball from hands my brother ran up to it and caught it! After he caught it he shouted "I did it" and I looked at him proudly and said "good job" he ran inside to tell my parents that he finally caught it. I was really glad that I had token the time to help him. I knew he could do it no matter how many times I tried or he tried. I knew he would get it soon. And he did! And that was the time I was patient.

Patience can mean a lot of things. It can mean to be understanding or it can mean to be tolerant. Being patient can also mean you don’t complain. If you are getting a new pair of shoes but the only way you can get them is they have to be ordered. You should not start to complain if it takes a long time. You should be able to wait without getting angry that you don’t have them yet. Being patient also involves remaining calm and composed when faced with delays or setbacks. If a project at work is taking longer than expected, a patient person will continue to work diligently without becoming frustrated. Being patient can mean all of these things. If you do these things you can tell that you are patient. That is what being patient means, and understanding its many facets allows us to better practice it in our daily lives.

When dealing with toddlers or the elderly you must have patience. This patience is key when dealing with anyone, but very young and very old need more. Elderly often can become confused, have a hard time hearing you, or just be a bit slower than you. You must practice patience and give them respect. Very young children are confused sometimes too because they are just learning. Toddlers will often become upset and refuse to do what you tell them if you have no patience with them and start to yell. Patience is also important for mentally or physically challenged persons. If they are challenged, there is no way that they can help it. Mentally challenged people often don't understand or don't want to do things just like toddlers. Be patient with the physically challenged because some tasks can be hard for them to complete. Be patient with everyone because patience is respect. Fear is not respect. That is how I feel about the word patience. Therefore, showing patience is a fundamental way of demonstrating respect and understanding towards others, regardless of their age or abilities.

A time when I was patient was when I was babysitting and the kids I was babysitting were acting up. It was hard for me to get them to calm down, as they were running around and yelling. So I told them that again, in a calm voice, and this time they were a bit quieter; I noticed that if I ignored them or was patient then they would settle down and stop because they were trying to get my attention. If I was being patient then I knew they would be too. It worked; they settled down and were being a lot better when I was babysitting them the next time too, showing me that patience can truly be effective in managing difficult situations.

I was on my way to Tennessee with my family, my older sister Sarah, my younger brother, Michael, and my grandpa and grandma, who I call Granny and Grandpop. We were driving in two different cars; I was with Sarah and my mom in Sarah's white Mercedes. Michael was with Grandpop and Granny in Granny's gold minivan. The windows were down in our car, and Sarah and I were smelling burning rubber. We were in front of the minivan, as we slowed down, Granny pulled to the side of us and told us to pull over. We pulled over, Mom got out, took one look, and said "We're leaking trannie fluid." We drove into town with Granny following us. We stopped at an auto shop. We were the only people there. The mechanic told us to get everything we needed out of the car. After we cleaned the car out, he pulled the car up onto the lift, and that's when I saw the garage for the first time. It smelled like gas, everything was greasy and dirty (including the mechanics). "This is going to ruin our trip," I said to Mom. "We don't know that for sure," she replied. It was so hard to sit and be patient. I walked back and forth between the minivan and the garage for about two hours. Some of the other mechanics came, too, but no one could find out what was wrong with our car. Mom got on the computer they had there and looked up car parts, it didn't help. The day before we left, Sarah had taken her car to the local garage for a tune-up. We weren't sure if that was related. After sitting at the shop for about three hours, I got hungry, so did everyone else, so we went to a restaurant across the street for lunch. Mom stayed at the shop for a little while longer than the rest of us. At lunch, Mom said "We're going to have to call Triple A to come pick up our car. We are going to have to go back home!!" I was so upset, after all this waiting, we have to go back home. On the way out of the restaurant, I tripped and landed on my wrist. I sprained my wrist, so we went back across the street, and behind the auto shop was a Walmart, so we stopped there, got a bandage for my wrist, and picked out a book to buy. I got the Vampire Diaries, Michael got a Star Wars book. We read them on the way home in Dad's car, a disappointing end to a trip that never truly began.

ìItís where?î The woman asked for the third time. ìDown the hall, to the left of the bathrooms,î I said for what had to be the fiftieth time. I grimaced as she walked out of the showroom, she didnít say anything. My dad worked for a small company that produced gift-shop-like knickknacks, like snow globes and the like. He offered me a summer job after my sixth grade year helping him out at work. Little did I know that what he was saying meant traveling to Chicago, standing in the middle of the hallway at a huge building, and telling people where his showroom was. When working in the manufacturing and trade industry, you often donít meet the smartest, well-educated people. You really need patience if you want to get anywhere. ìTwo dollars an hour, two dollars an hour.î I muttered to myself as a middle-aged man walked up to me. He read my name tag that had the blue- and- white company logo of Youngís Incorporated. ìHey, youíre with Youngís?î he asked. ì Do you know where the show room is?î I could tell what he was thinking. Why was an adolescent working for a cooporation? ìDown the hall, to the left of the bathrooms.î I said in a robotic voice. ìArenít you a little young to be doing this kind of work?î he asked. You were expecting maybe an intern? I thought hastily, but I instead replied with a complacent ìNo, sir.î ìHow old are you?î he asked quizzically. ìSixteen, sir.î I lied. I knew I could pass for a high ñschooler, so I knew heíd believe me. I was really wishing that he would move along, because I getting pretty edgy. I was already beginning to imagine what would happen if I grabbed his tie and yanked on it as hard as I could. Doing this all day was not healthy. ìAre you getting paid?î Not enough to put up with the likes of you. I thought. I took a deep breath, and answered, ìyes, sir. But itís not a lot. Itís more like volunteer work, really.î Please donít ask any more questions, I thought. He smiled and walked on, ìthanks son.î ìYouíre welcome.î I said through partially clenched teeth. I think weíll both agree that I was patient that day. And I hope that that man bought a boatload of stuff from my dadís shop, because if he didnít, I will be very put out, proving that even the most patient person has their limits. That is the time when I was the most patient.

Lost in Harriman State Park was early October, the leaves just beginning to change colors and flutter down above your head. My mother, sister, a friend of hers and I all piled into the car and drove a few minutes to the state park, which was literally in our backyard. I had my camera and I'm very thorough at getting a shot of everything. My mother and the others were very patient with me, letting me be slow on the hike. The thing about Harriman State Park is that there aren't very many trail maps so you can easily become confused or lost. After hiking a long way we come to a folk in the road where a map was. My mother checked her cell phone and told us we had forty-five minutes until we had to take our new kitten to the vet. I suggested we start heading back so we could get home in time to pick up the kitten and arrive on time, permitting the long drive to the vets. My mother instead of taking my advice, started us off in the completely different direction. My sister and her friend complained dragging their feet. For the next mile or so we continued without finding a map. My sister and I became increasingly frustrated with my mother and with being lost. Because we had gotten lost in the monotonous field and trees my mother had to get out her dying cell phone and call my father to bring my kitten to the vet. I was looking forward to taking him, making me further stressed. Finally after another half hour of walking we ended up at the exit. I was happy I almost kissed the car. Everything turned out all right and my mother was always patient with us we complained and moaned.

A beaker bubbled in the university lab. I could smell the sulfur smell wafting from the beaker. “What’s going on!” I yelped across the room. “I found the cure for the cancer!” he said as he had a little jublee dance that he showed off. I am a doctor and I wasn’t so sure but I told him I had a patient with extreme brain cancer. “Let’s go try it out!” he screamed. As I zoomed to the car, I waited while he packed up his lab equipment. After 10 minutes I was pondering where he could be. He’s just having a hard time packing up I said. So I turned on the radio and fell asleep. After a couple hours I woke up in shock. I had been sleeping 2 hours! I rushed inside to find him holding a ball of fur wrapped in his lab coat. “I saved this kitten’s life with my cure for cancer.” he said out of breath. I was glad I was patient or the kitten would have not lived. Just as I was thinking about how nice it was that he saved the kitten, my pager dinged. Mrs. Johnson, the lady with extreme brain cancer needed our help. He got one vial of his cancer solution and we rushed to the hospital. There I saw Mrs. Johnson laying there as translucent as light hitting off paper. I quickly got her heart rate down. At this moment I wasn’t sure if she would live. “Should I give it to her?” the mad scientist asked. I made a risky choice. “No, not yet.” I waited five minutes and then poured it in. Mrs. Johnson came back to life. Even though Mrs. Johnson couldn’t talk, I could tell by her smile that she was very thankful I was patient. Her daughter walked into the room and said, “Thank you.” I only smiled back, knowing the value of patience had ultimately contributed to a life saved.

I remember one day I was waiting in the waiting room in the doctors office with my mom because I wasn’t feeling well. We sat there talking for about ten minutes when my mom said “Wow it’s already been ten minutes.” “I wonder when I will get to go and talk to my doctor,” I said. “I don’t know but lets wait a bit longer,” Mom said. So as we waited and sat patiently more kids started coming in. I noticed some were young and some were older. I sighed. What is taking so long? I wondered. Was my doctor even here today? I stared at the wall and looked at the color of it. Orange. Before I knew it half an hour passed. My mom was looking at her watch. “Wow it’s almost noon!” “Finally!” I said flustered and annoyed. “Are we just gonna sit here all day?” I asked. Finally my question was answered as a nurse said I could finally come back to a room and speak with my doctor about my sickness. “Thanks for being patient!” the nurse said smiling. I smiled back. I had been patient.

Patience can come in different ways in life. For one thing, it can reward you at the end. For example, if you are patient with your investments, it can come in a bigger way because the returns would be a bigger reward to you. Another thing is that it lets you do other things in the process. For example, while you could wait for a package to arrive, you could do something else when it's time for you to receive it. Another thing is that it might be difficult, but you can control it if you're calm. For example, people can't wait, so they just want to rush and get to be done with it, leading to mistakes. My final reason would be if you can do it once in your life, the second time can be easy. For example, the second time wouldn't be so hard because you would be calmer and more prepared. That is patience in my own way, and it showcases how beneficial it can truly be.

Tap, tap, tap. The tips of my fingers bounced off the arm rest with every movement. I had asked my MOM to hurry up BECAUSE I didn’t want to be late. I had told her like I have a million times before, “MOM, you know how much being on time for practice means to me.” BECAUSE I sat there slumped over on the couch, my backpack strapped tightly over my shoulders. This happens ALL the time, I thought my MOM would have learned by now. As I waited, I turned on the television to keep me busy. Unfortunately, with every flip, I became more irritated. “WHERE is she? Why is she taking SO long?” Thoughts like these swirled in my head. Then, my MOM came stumbling into the family room. She snatched her keys and we hurried into the car. As I snapped my seat belt into place, I flipped the switch to open the garage. As I sat in my seat, wiggling, the garage door creaked open. My MOM started the engine and we cascaded down the driveway and towards the road. Just to make my luck even better, we got caught in traffic. As the cars sauntered along, time was ticking away. The clock showed 3:15, I for sure knew that I wasn’t going to make it on time. I threw myself back into the seat. I closed my EYES and took deep breaths. Taking lots of deep breaths helped slow down my heart rate which allowed me to tone down my stress level. “BE patient.” I told myself. “BE patient. Relax, you’ll make it there.” ALL of a sudden my MOM slammed onto the brakes. My eyes flew open to see that we had made it to the pool. The time read 3:29. I was going to make it! I exploded out of the car with my bag on my back. At that moment, I told myself “see you can do it. You made it to swim practice, and ALL you had to do was slow down and BE patient. Great job!”

When I was 8 years old my mother and sister were working and cleaning around the house and I kept asking ìcan we go to get pizza?î But every time I asked she would reply, ìif you help us and we finish before dinner, we can go get pizzaî. I didnít want to wash windows, clean my room or wash the car. So I waited on the playground in the back yard swinging and going down the slide, but after 20 minutes, it got boring. After that, thats when I knew I would have to be patient. I ran down the hill to the river and waded into its cold water. But I was still bored. I got out of the river and ran to Mom. ìMom and Sarah are you done yet?î I asked. ìWere done with the house but the car has yet to be washedî she answered. I walk to my bike and got my helmet which is sitting on my bike seat. The wind in my face was nothing compared to eating pizza, but somehow driving up and down the drive way was more entertaining than cleaning. I hop of my bicycle and ran into the house, taking two immediate lefts after entering the house I look up at the clock, 4:25 p.m it said. My family always has dinner at 5:35 because my dad gets home from work at 5:00 and cooks dinner. I rush to see if my Mom and sister were done yet, ìAre you done?î I asked rudely. ìYou could help if you want it to fasterî Mom answers. ìOkay, fine Iíll helpî, I grab the hose and spray the dirt and bird poop off the windows. After 15 minutes of cleaning we were done, Mom left dad a note and she said, ìlets do!î After the whole day I waited 6 hours for my Mom and sister to finish, in the end I finished the job, which taught me patience and the value of contributing to a shared goal.

One day when I was patient was when we all had to go on the same ride at Six Flags. It seemed like everyone was determined to go on this one ride, and there were tons of people in line for it. I had to wait patiently in line because I was in the back, and we were there for about half an hour waiting to go on the ride. After we waited there patiently, the ride was dumb; it did not even go up five sets of stairs. After that letdown, we went on a whole bunch of water park rides and then went home, ending the day on a much more fun note.

Patience in my words is to be able to wait a long time for something and not be angry and not raise your blood pressure. Patience is a good thing to have because if you didn’t have patience you would probably never be able to accomplish anything that takes time to do. I think that being patient would help you succeed in many things. For an example, me and my mom were in the @ORGANIZATION1 drive through and the lady in front of us was yelling at the people in the line to go faster; when you do something like that, it’s most likely not going to speed things up. My mom has outstanding patience because she can wait for things for hours and not get frustrated. I rarely have patience; I can't wait more than around ten minutes for something. Patience is a great thing because you most likely won’t get things done without it. Most of my family and I don’t have the best patience, but we sometimes do. I think that patience is very good to have, and it is a virtue worth cultivating to lead a more successful and peaceful life.

My mom wasn't patient because when I came home late from the park she was impatient, but she wasn't patient when she took the phone away from me, she wasn't patient. When my brother gets in trouble, she has patience for him and my sister but none for me. Just because I came home 15 minutes late, she said she had patience before I did that, and now she has a little bit of patience for me, just a little. It feels unfair because it seems her patience is conditional, varying based on who's involved and what happened.

A time when I was patient is when it was winter time and my cousin and I really wanted to go outside. My mom kept saying “you will be able to go out.” My cousin was very mad; she was having a fit. I was just sitting there on my couch, calmly telling her what my mom said. After an hour passed, I was able to go outside, but my cousin could not because she wasn’t being patient. That is a time when I was patient, and it taught me that sometimes waiting is the best course of action.

One time I was patient because I was hunting; it was a cold October play. I was sitting in a blind with my dad, waiting for a deer. It was almost eight o'clock, and we had been out there since five. We heard the ducks and geese making noises in the marshland next to us; we could see the trees dance in the wind, smell the damp grass, and the morning fog. Then, out of nowhere at 7:45 AM, there came a doe. They went by us with caution, so I got the gun ready. Then out came the eight-point buck; I shot him through the heart and lung. I also gutted him. The year was 2018; in the youth hunt, I was patient, and it paid off, showing that patience can be a virtue in hunting.

Being patience is like being a good person. If you are patient, then good things will inhere to you. Some patient people got some good rewards like moving, promotions, and opportunities but some patience that you do could bring you the bad outcome. Patience is a talent that is difficult to master. Patience is a mental game, testing our limits and resolve. Patience comes into everyone's life, presenting challenges both big and small. If you have no patience, then therefore you have more anger, a consequence of unmet expectations. Patience for those minors stuck in a mine for two months highlights its importance in dire circumstances. College takes a seal of years, demanding sustained effort and commitment. Patience is required there also, to navigate academic hurdles and personal growth. Patience is among people everywhere, whether it's waiting for a toy or waiting for God to save you; patience is something that will stay here forever, a constant companion in the human experience, shaping our reactions and defining our character.

This is a story of the time I was patient. It was four in the morning, I was in bed sleeping. It was dead silent. All of a sudden, I woke up to the sound of footsteps, it was my dad. Out of nowhere, my bright light flashed on and I squinted and put the blanket over my head. My dad yelled, “it’s time to go, bud!” I replied “okay!” I quickly flung out of bed, got dressed, ate breakfast, grabbed my bag and put it in the trunk of my mom’s car. It was the middle of summer, and we were on our way to Disneyland. I knew I had to be patient, so I popped a movie in the DVD player for me and my brother Mark to watch. It started to get lighter out and I was still watching movies while everyone else was asleep. Except for my dad of course, he was the driver. When everyone woke up we stopped for food and gas. I was very patient, because I had to wait for everyone to wake up before I got to eat. After we ate we got back in the car and drove off. A couple hours later, we got to Disneyland. I was excited to get there, I burst out of the car and yelled “finally!” That was the story of how I was patient.

The last time I was patient was yesterday. Because we had to go to Chicago city to pick something up and it took about 30 long minutes. Then on the way back we took another 30 long minutes; on both trips it was boring. But I had to be patient; also, just this morning I had to be patient because my brother was taking a shower, and I wanted to, so I had to be patient because he takes like 15 minutes. Earlier today we were having chocolate milk; my mom was gonna make it, and we had to be patient for her to make it, showing that patience is often needed throughout the day.

Patience is important. If you don’t have patience you can get angry easily. You will have a lot more friends if you are patient, as people appreciate a calm and understanding demeanor. Patience always leads to good things, fostering better relationships and outcomes. A lot of times people are doing something and they get impatient. It would have been a lot easier if they were patient and approached the task with a clear mind, highlighting that patience is truly a virtue that smooths life's challenges.

Sometimes when people take a long time, my family is patient. My dad has to be patient because when he gets deployed to a new country, he has to wait such a long time to come back and see his family again. My mom has to be patient because sometimes her co-workers, or even the people there, really get on her nerves. My brother has to be patient because he always has something in the mail that he's always waiting for. My sister is patient because she has to handle both me and my brother. Both me and my brother are patient because we have to sit on an hour-long bus ride with nothing to do but sit there and look bored. My siblings are also patient and wait for the school year to end. My dad is also patient because he has to finish his bait decks, which is taking a long time, plus all the whining from my sister and mom about why we don't need one. I'm always patient when I have to get the school day over with; my brother can be patient when he has to sit and wait for about thirty minutes at a time for his computer to load. In short, my family is really patient, whether it's sitting in the office or deployed to a new country; my family is always patient, displaying a remarkable ability to endure delays and frustrations.

Have you ever been patient? At some times, people lose their patience at many things. Examples of losing patience can be waiting in a line to go on a roller-coaster, because sometimes that can take forever. The anticipation and slow progress can be frustrating. Having patience can be a good thing. You're calm and you don’t have to be upset at somethings like waiting in a line somewhere for a long time. Being a patient person also means that you have the ability to wait for something, unlike people without patience, because those people will struggle while waiting for something. They may become agitated or give up easily. In conclusion, I think that having patience will sometimes help you to succeed in life. If you're un-patient than you should try not to be because the thing you want or you're waiting for will eventually happen someday, and remaining calm will make the process much easier.

It was a light breezy morning. It was 6:00 AM, my parents were just finishing the packing for our trip to Colorado. We're going to Colorado because my sister has a lacrosse tournament in Denver. Now we were 8 hours in and we were in Colorado. We started seeing mountains. They were wonderful. 4 hours through. We decided to watch the *Cars* movie for the last hour. The hour went by like a flash. Finally done, that is a time I was sort of patient.

Back when I was in about third grade I had to be really patient. I was at a @ORGANIZATION1 game. It was almost the seventh inning and I was ready to go onto the field. For some people it is as hard as a rock, but to some it just comes naturally. Patience is a big part of hunting. You must be tolerant and understanding. Even if things seem to take a turn for the worst. Take this for example. I had woke up at six and jumped out of bed. I was finally going to shoot my first deer! I pulled on my camofage and hunterís orange as my grandpa drove down my long drive way to get me. The moon light shone bright and I was giggling with exitment, but I knew I had to calm down. As we drove to the place I was going to hunt I was amazed by how quite evreything was. We walked back to the blind on a leaf covered trail and set evrething in itís place. After, dosing of a little the morning light seemed to peek through the trees and light up the fresh green field. The water vapor looked like sparkles floting in mid air. We heard a grouse drum and had a red squarle jump out at us, but no deer. After a long morning of sitting we disided to pack up our gear. We always had tomarrow to try again. Patience may not always help in ways you wish, but it can help you see many diffrent and beautiful things.

One time Mom took a test to become a CNA. That means certified nursing assistant. After she took the test she was very nervous. She waited and waited. A phone call would come very soon but she had to have patience. The first day she took the test it was very hard to have patience. I understood because I get that feeling when I’m waiting for test results. It is nerve racking and exciting. The next day was not as hard. She just went on with her day. The third day of waiting she started wondering if the call would come. Later that day the phone rang. A smile spread across her face. She had passed the test. This is a time Mom showed patience for three whole days!

It can be really hard to be patient, depending on the effect. Even I lose my patience some times. But one time I was so patient that I was about to explode. On a dry summer day, July 15th, 2018, my family and I decide to go on an exciting vacation to Niagara Falls. We drove from Toronto to Niagara-on-the-Lake and headed east towards Niagara Falls. After the boring road trip, we parked our silver mini van in a five dollar parking lot right next to the Niagara Falls. First we went up the Skylon tower, where we saw everything from the incredible height. After that we saw our cousins. I never even saw them before. As we were looking at the waterfall my brother said, "Wow, look at those boats under the waterfall. Dad, can we go on them?" "Yes, but first we have to buy tickets." Said my dad. We bought the tickets and went in line." Why are there so much people?" I asked. There was about 100 people waiting in line with us. "Just be patient," my dad replied. I stood there looking at all the people in front of us. We were never going to get on the boat. I saw people handing out blue rain jackets. After twenty minutes we still did not get the jackets yet. We were moving as slow as the plates on the earth were. Finally, we got a jacket, but we weren't on a boat yet. My brother was complaining and my dad started yelling at him. I was still standing, almost to explode. At last, they called us up onto the boat. It was amazing going under the waterfall. We were in the mist. When we came back to shore, we talked about how amazing it was. Being patient has a reward at the end. Even though it is hard to be patient, I still did it and anyone can. I was patient the whole time in line to get in the boat. Patience can be rewarding, and in this case, it led to an unforgettable experience.

In third grade one day it was one of my happiest days of my life. It was the day when we were going to get our dog Goldie and I was excited and as patient as ever. It was a cold winter's day and it was my time to go to school and I couldn't wait till the school day was over because it was the day when we got Goldie. When I got to school I couldn't wait to tell everyone that today was the day. When school ended my mom came to pick up my sister and I from school to go home and wait patiently at home for my dad and Goldie to come home. When we got home my mom and my two sisters and I were waiting patiently in the living room watching T.V. just listening for the garage door to open. And then we heard it open and we all were jumping up and down running and screaming outside and there she was Goldie the best dog in the world. That's the way I was patient on the winter's day waiting patiently for the best dog in the world, and it was truly worth the wait.

It was a normal old boring day in the summer but I had just got a call from my sister in law. She literally just called me and asked if I wanted to go to Cedar Point the next day. I was astonished! I didn’t know what to say! At first I thought she was hiding around but when she asked to talk to my mom, I knew she was legit. When she was done talking to my mom, my mom too was in shock. My sister in law Kelly was very impressed on how patiently I waited. And we went to the car to get some food. It was the best food I had ever aten. The rest of the day was tremendous but that was defidintly the most patient I was in my entire life. Due to the fact that it was just me and Kelly, I think that’s why I was so calm. Even though that part of the day hind of sucked it was still our all a great time!

This year mom married my new step dad. I guess he wanted us to bond so we took up trap shooting. It's pretty much the same thing as skeet shooting, well actually it is the same. Anyway he used to be a cop and had a shotgun so we went out and tried it. It didn't work out. I missed every single bird, I clay targets except one. I only got one bb through the thing. A time when I was patient is when our family goes to Six Flags. My family and I go to Six Flags a lot. Usually, the lines are very long, sometimes over an hour! Once, on my first time on the Goliath, the wait was two hours, but we went anyway. We were about half an hour in and then they had some technical difficulties. I was glad I had enough patience to wait in those long lines.

Patience means that you are understanding and tolerant. A patient person experiences difficulties without complaining; most people are impatient these days. I think the world would be more peaceful if everybody had patience; there would be no more conflict, and if that happened some day, everybody's lives would be perfect, fostering a more harmonious and understanding global community.

Being patient is a very hard thing to do, most people are very bad at it but some are good. I am one of the people that are bad at it. The hardest thing I have ever done in my entire life is wait in line for three and a half hours just to ride the dragster at Cedar Point. It was a very hot and sticky July 14th day and Cedar Point was packed. There were flies everywhere, tickling your legs, buzzing in your ear, and even biting you. You could hear the screams from a mile away overweight people were wearing shorts and tank-tops, eating popcorn. It was brutal! I had ridden every ride except for the dragster. The dragster is the ride that takes you up to the very top and shoots you down as fast as a bullet. The only problem, if you wanted first cart, which I did, it was a three and a half hour wait! “Can I just go ride the skyscraper again” I pleaded. “NO! I came all the way to Cedar Point; I am not going to leave without riding the best funnest ride! You are going to stand in this line and wait!” I quickly replied. “FINE! I never get what I want do I!” “You get everything you want. You can go ride the skyscraper again if you want but I am staying here! And I feel bad for whoever has to sit by you because they are going to have bruises and scratches all over the arms. Heck you might pop their eardrum from screaming so much!” “well I don’t wanna put somebody else throught that pain but you I might!” By the time I was done fighting there were only twenty minutes left, I didn’t get front cart the wait wasn’t even that bad. In the end, while the wait was excruciating, conquering my impatience to ride the Dragster made the experience worthwhile.

A time when I was patient was when I was helping a kid in my class on his project. We were doing a science project and this kid didnít understand anything about it. He would put things in the wrong place, write down things that didnít go with science, and he didnít listen to anything so he was correctly but he lost it! I am never patient. Whether it's waiting for dinner or waiting for a friend, I am never patient. The only time I can be patient is when I'm waiting for school to start. My cousin was patient when we were waiting in line for the top thrill ride at Cedar Point. The line almost took two hours. My cousin was just simply silent (very unusual) and just waiting. Have you ever been patient? I have, especially this one main time in my life. That one main time in my life was when I was waiting for my dog to have her babies. My dog’s name is Dixie mae; she is three years old and is a full-blooded pitbull. It all started when we took Dixie to the vet for her early check-up. The vet said she was all good, then pulled my mom to the side. My heart was pumping faster than ever because usually when they pull the parents to the side it means something bad. My mom screamed and rejoiced. I ran to her, and she screamed “Dixie is going to have babies!” Then I screamed with her. We went and got Dixie, and then we took her to the dog park, and that night, she got her very own steak at supper. The next few months were going by faster than ever, well, at least it seemed like it. Now Dixie was getting bigger. The vet said it should be six months at least until she has the puppies. It’s already been five and a half months; mom said that she has milk now. I told my sister, July 18th. “I wouldn’t doubt it,” said July 18th. Then we went and took Dixie inside for the night. The next day, while I was getting ready for school, my mom said, “Hey sweetheart, I called the vet, and he said that he wouldn’t be surprised if Dixie had her puppies today!” Then I said, “Oh, cool, but let’s not rush Dixie; she’s going through a lot right now.” Then we said our goodbyes, and I went to the bus stop. The bus ride usually takes like an hour to school, but today, it only felt like thirty minutes. The day was going by fast. Before I knew it, I was home. I walked in the front door, and my mom said, “Oh, you're just in time, honey; Dixie's having her babies!” We both ran into the garage faster than ever. Dixie was laying on a blanket. I jotted to her, and she licked my hand. I told her everything is going to be alright. I went inside to get her a bowl of water and some soft food, and when I came back out, she already had two puppies. It took about an hour for the other two and then another hour for the other two after them. Turns out they were all girls. Now we have ten dogs at my house: the mom, Dixie mae, the dad, Buster, and all eight little girl puppies: Cutie, Bootsier, Tinker, Bella, Harmony, and Melony. I love my dogs, and being patient through the whole process made it even more rewarding.

Just before winter break, in the fourth grade, there was a Christmas party at my neighborís house. My parents and I were invited, and since we didnít have plans, we decided to go to the party. The party was spectacular! There were stockings hung over the fireplace, green and red streamers everywhere, and huge Christmas tree in the living room. Under the Christmas tree, there was a large pile of presents-each one for the children. My neighbor saw me staring at the presents, so he walked over, picked up a present, and handed it to me. The present was a rectangular shape wrapped in blue gift wrap decorated with snowflakes. On the front was my name in marker. I was about to open my present when my neighbor told me to wait. He said that if I opened it now, I would only get one gift. If I waited until Christmas morning to open it, I would get two gifts. I didnít understand it at first, but he said I soon would. Christmas was a week away! How in the world was I suppose to wait until then? Of course I wanted two gifts, so I told my neighbor I would wait. Deep down inside though, I wanted to tear the present right open. The days dragged on. Why was the week going by so slowly? As Christmas drew near, I grew impatient. I almost opened my present three days before Christmas. Finally, on the twenty-fifth of December, I was able to open my present. Instead of quickly unwrapping it like I planned to, I slowly tore the paper awayÖ and found a lovely velvet diary with golden boarders. Inside was a note: Not only have you earned yourself a new diary, you now have the gift of patience. Now I understood that the true gift was not just the diary itself, but the ability to learn self-control and delayed gratification, a lesson that has proven valuable throughout my life.

Patience is a key role in life; without it, unhappiness often follows. Almost everything in life calls for patience. Impatience can disrupt things, such as your job if you are not patient with your boss or co-workers, potentially leading to conflicts and misunderstandings. I often have a hard time being patient with my mom and dad. Sometimes I just can't stand my parents anymore and I lose my temper and become impatient with them, and that usually makes things worse for me and strains our relationship. I do love my brother, but he can get really annoying, like most little brothers and sisters do, often testing my limits. When my brother gets on my nerves, I become very impatient with him. Sometimes I will get so mad and impatient with him I will just lose it, and I always get in trouble when I beat on him, and I would always end up being the bad guy because of my impatience and the consequences of my actions. Now that I am older, I realize how important it is to be patient with people; it makes life a whole lot easier and fun with the people I'm around every day. That is why when you are patient, you will get your way, but when you are impatient because you are trying to get your way, it will never happen. Ultimately, cultivating patience leads to smoother interactions and more positive outcomes in various aspects of life.

Ultimately, having patience helps me navigate challenges and succeed in school and life.

"Mom, forest, are we there yet?" Lily asked with curiosity. "Sigh, not yet," Elara replied with a sound of fear in her voice. They were lost, really lost. "Are we there yet?" little Lily asked again. "Sigh, Lily, you’ll just have to be patient," Grandma said, becoming annoyed very quickly. So they walked for hours, but still no sign of the castle. Little Lily was eager to meet the queen, for she had imagined the queen as a kind, patient, beautiful woman. Grandma could tell that Lily was tired, lifting her on her shoulders she said to Lily, "See if you can spot the castle from here Lily." After a few long patient minutes, Lily finally saw the castle "I see it, I see it!" she said with a smile. Jumping off of Grandma’s shoulder, she bolted down the narrow path way because she had waited, she was as excited as ever, not only because she had found the castle but because she learned how to be patient.

A time I was patient was when I got my braces. I was so nervous, so it was hard to be patient. I waited in the waiting room for about fifteen minutes, then the assistant called me in. First, she told me what she was going to do; second, she took an x-ray of my teeth; third, she put metal bands with a really strong glue on the back of my teeth; fourth, the orthodontist put the brackets on with really strong glue. Then the assistant put the wire between the brackets and metal bands; finally, she asked me what color I wanted, then she put them on, and I was free to go. The whole process took two hours, and I had to sit in a dental chair for that long. I had a lot of patience; it was hard, but I did it. That is the time I had patience, and I felt very proud of myself for getting through it.

Patience is being polite by waiting for someone or something. It is polite to be patient; if you're not, you are practically mean because you are judging someone or making them do something really fast. For example, if you are waiting in line for a ride at a carnival, then if you are patient, you're being nice to other people by not trying to hurry them. If you are impatient and standing in line, you would be mean to other people by saying, "Hurry up! I want to be on that ride already!" If you are a patient person, people will probably like you. If you are impatient, then you will probably have a hard time getting along with somebody, as people appreciate those who are considerate and understanding of their pace. Therefore, patience is a virtue that fosters positive relationships.

Being patient is one of the many things children are taught while growing. They mature and we use these life lessons & life guidences when they need them. Being patient can sometimes be very hard, especially, when whatever you are being patient about is really distracting and painful. "Mom! I fell!" I managed to scream between sobs. "Oh my gosh! Let me go find some band aids," my mother replied. The pain was intolerable for my little body. I kept silently crying but I knew I had to be patient while my mom went to look for bandages. Just yesterday I had wasted a bunch of band aids by plastering them across my doll's face. I had to be patient and wait for a long time, till my mother finally found the bandages. "I found them!" my mom said, while running down the stairs. "Are you okay? Thank you for being so patient." Patience means being understanding and tolerant. I find patience difficult to come by, along with many other people. Some people are graced with the gift of patience. Those people find it easy to wait even when it’s the night the finale of your favorite book series comes out. "Tick tock," the clock taunted me by moving slower than ever. Why Mom wasn’t back yet I didn’t know. All I knew was going to happen that night was a very bad thing. It must have been the unbearable heat getting to me because when the door slammed shut Mom argued that Dad’d only been gone for five fast minutes. I didn’t believe her, but we climbed into the car and drove down the twisty, turning road. We had timed our car ride perfectly to see red lights at every stoplight. It was like the lights were mad at us. We also got stuck behind every slow person with no way to get around them. Just as I had a scream budding inside me we saw a green light and cruised into town. Coming up on my right came the book store and my jitters became more uncontrollable. I bounced up and down like I was on a trampoline and stopped the split second I saw the line in front of us. "No!," I shouted, "I don’t have any patience left to wait in this monstrosity of a line." It was like the whole town was in on making me annoyed as possible. I lugged the lawn chairs from our van to wait in line. Flop – I fell into the black chair and waited. This was going to be a long night. "Ten minutes till midnight" my sister explained to me "That’s impossible" I told her. "You can make it." Dad was right, ten minutes wasn’t that long of a wait. I breathed in the smell of coffee coming from inside and listened to the hum of chatter among the people. The ten minutes would be over soon, and for the first time that night I was patient. "Click" the seatbelt went into place and I cracked open the final book of the "Star Wars" trilogy. What will happen? How is it going to end? My mind was full of questions. "Was that wait really that bad?" Mom asked. "I guess not" I answered sheepishly. "Being patient payed off!" my sister lectured. I didn’t reply; I was already reading a mile a minute. I learned being patient really does pay off and not complaining makes life a lot easier. Patient is understanding and knowing that I’m a little better at being patient things will be a lot better.

You have heard before: patience is a virtue. If you don’t know already, being patient means you are understanding and tolerant. The opposite of this probably having a temper, or having a very short time before you get angry. I believe having patience in life is very important, and I try to have patience every day. I believe that life is a marathon, not a sprint, and by this I mean if something takes time, you have lots of it. I related life to sports, because I am a pretty good athlete. I play football, which also requires lots of patience. When I make a good pass and my reciever drops it, I remember to have patience with him, just as my coach did with me. Football is a team game, and we all have to have patience with each other. Although sports are a great example, patience goes much furthur than that, you must have patience with yourself before you can have patience with others. And what do I mean by that? Whether you’re a kid or an adult, you must forgive yourself when you do wrong. If you come in late for work, you must brush it off and say to yourself, “Okay, don’t do it again.” Ensure that you forget about everything but what you just said. And once again I go back to sports. If you lose a game, you look at the film, realize what you did wrong, and don’t make those mistakes again. Then, you forget about the loss and concitrate on winning next game. I believe patience is one of the most important virtue a person can have, and consistently practicing it will inevitably lead to a better and more fulfilling life.

I think patience comes into play in a lot of places. For example, you have to be patient to get a job, or else the boss will kick you right out of the building without saying one word to you. Lastly, if you have to wait for something and not get it right away, like with money from your job, you don't just go rob the place; you have to be patient and you have to wait for payday. Cultivating this virtue is essential for navigating life's challenges and achieving long-term goals.

Book "And the characters lived happily ever after…for now!" Lily shut the book, very sad that no more pages were left. My name is ninth on the list, but it could be ages until those other people finish.” “Honey, I think you have to learn some patience” said mom. “Patience? What’s that?” asked Lily “Patience is when you wait for something, and you don’t complain about it. Take you, for example, your being very impatient.” “But I’m waiting” said Lily “No, honey, you are complaning a whole lot.” The next day, Lily was as patient as she could be. She did not go to the library and ask for the book, and she went the whole without complaining. Later on. Lily was called to the office. When she got there, she found Mrs. Davis and Mrs. Smith, the secretary. “Lily!” said Mrs. Davis. “What’s this?” asked Lily “This is the book you wanted. A long wait. I was only four at the time. I had moved to Georgia. Yes, moved to Michigan, Georgia from Texas. Quite a long way down south for me but I was a young little girl who didn’t care too, too much. So I lived in Georgia, went to kindergarden, made friends, moved into a new house, and so on until I was seven. That is when I found out that we were moving. Again, back to Michigan. Well, now I wasn’t four anymore. I had a lot of amazing friends here (in particular two of them) and now I would have to start all over again. I didn’t hate the idea but I didn’t love it either. Of course. It didn’t exactly matter. We were moving anyway and I knew from the beginning that I would easily have fun and make new friends. The only thing I didn’t want to leave behind were the old friends, memories, and all the other stuff I loved about this place. So I took along my memories, promised to keep in touch with friends, and then moved. Novi was different but good. There were plenty of changes to adjust to but it was pretty easy overall. I made plenty of new friends with which I now hang out with everyday. I’ve slipped into life here like you slip into bed every night. What I do is fun and feels like normal. I have now been living here for four years. I have been exchanging letters, emails, events, and memories with friends down in Georgia and friends here all this time. But even so, I long to go back down for a visit. I have been patiently waiting for it to happen. Now, I think that patience is paying off, because I finally get to visit this year. My only difficult has been that I don’t get to see everyone. But not for long. I see all my friends here all the time and now I’ll get to see my older friends too. Yipee for me! I can’t wait! For years of waiting has provided me with an opportunity to reconnect with cherished friendships and revisit a beloved place, making the upcoming visit all the more meaningful.

I walked into the big open room. The smell of crayon, animal crackers and dirt overcome the air and hit my nose like a big wave rolling in from the sea. I take my first nervous steps into the room. The floor is covered with toys and a lot of crayons. The kindergartners are running around screaming like little animals that heard they were about to be eaten for dinner. The teacher is standing right in the middle of it all. She has a distant look in her eyes and she looks like she’s about to cry. When she sees me and my name tag her face lights up a little bit. She practically runs at me with arms open. The teacher introduces herself then says they’re all mine. I never would have realized student teaching would have me doing so much teaching. I knew I’d do a little but as the teacher introduced herself, then said she was leaving and I had to teach them the alphabet. So I was stuck with 25 kids and a “war.” I eventually, with some grabbing and pulling involved, get the kids to sit down criss-cross apple sauce on the floor. It’s too bad I underestimated how wild they were. As I begin, one of kids starts throwing toys at me, so as calmly as possible I half growled, “NO BILLY, that’s not nice, please stop.” Billy stops for about two way too short seconds. So this repeats and I end up doing this with all the wild eyed, crazy haired dwarfs. It took a lot of stinking patience to get them to finally sit still. We got to about H when the kids got fussy again. At that point I was feeling more like a babysitter than a teacher. I was gradually understanding how that teacher was willing to leave. Finally I get that light bulb going off in my head feeling I run to my purse grab my bag of candy and say, “when we finish learning the alphabet A-Z, anyone who can say the whole thing will get a piece of candy!” I realized to them that’s like gold to an adult. I was amazed and couldn’t believe my ears. Every kid learned A-Z, I actually ran out of candy, although it took a lot of patience and pointless bickering. When the bell rings I hastily leave to go home. It took a lot of patience but I did it, and reward myself. I slept! The day was a challenge, but managing the chaos and successfully teaching them the alphabet, even with the help of sugary incentives, felt like a significant accomplishment, making the exhaustion well worth it.

The word patience means a lot of things. It can mean waiting for something and much more than that. It also talks a lot about enduring difficult situations. It takes time and effort to cultivate. I'm the type who complain a lot and I don't have patience. Other people, they don't complain; they handle it. A lot of teenagers have no patience. As you get older you develop patience, but some adults don't have patience; it depends on if you work at it. It also depends on what the person has gone through in life, as challenging experiences can shape one's capacity for patience. Ultimately, patience is a virtue that requires conscious effort and is often influenced by life's circumstances.

My mother is the most patient person I know. When she drops me off at practice she waits two and a half hours for me to cheer, fly, and dance the whole routine. When I go to science programs she waits at least two hours until it's over. Every morning she waits on me to finish getting ready, even when I take longer than expected. After school, she waits on me to buy something at the table in the lobby, patiently observing my choices. All that she asks is for us to return the favor, showing her the same consideration she gives us. She doesn't rush us unless we're late, understanding the importance of taking our time. And she always hugs us before we leave, a comforting reminder of her love and support, making her patience all the more appreciated.

Patience I was patient when I did not want to go to Wisconsin. I was patient on my way there (driving). I was patient when I was fishing, not complaining how boring it was. I wasn't happy about sleeping on the ground. The whole camping trip I was patient. Story begins. Wisconsin, took 7 hours. In the car had a t.v. I watched that for a while and then I looked outside and saw a moose! I screamed, ''moose!!'' my roomate's boyfriend, Mike, stopped and backed up and that was my first time seeing a moose. Then when we got there we set up our tent and then went fishing. I was patient for the fish to bite my worm. I was so patient I got 2 fish that day. Then when we came back i had to sleep on the ground. There were bumps and rocks under me, but I didn't complain because that's how camping is. The next day we were on our way back and I couldn't find the t.v. and didn't have a drink. I had to go to the bathroom. A sign said, "a gas station on exit 3". I was patient, went to the bathroom and to get a water. Because of my patience during the trip, I was able to enjoy the experience despite the inconveniences, and that made the trip worthwhile.

Patient is when you are listening and tolerant of how someone feels. My mom and dad are very patient with me and my sister. My sister just came and moved in with us; she is 20 years old. I look up to my parents; they are so nice to everyone, and even though it's different now, they are still patient, showing me the importance of understanding and compassion even when things are in flux.

I do not have patience. It's a feeling many experience, stemming from a desire for immediate results. Patience is a good thing to have. Good things come from patience and bad things dont happen. But what is patience? Patience is being able to handle problems without whining and complaining about them. Patience is being able to wait while others can’t. Some people are very impatient, such as my dad at some times. For a month or so he had been saving up his extra money for a new TV. One time when I had to be patient was when I had to babysit. My family friend has a one year old, And I have a six year old brother. I had to babysit both of them because my mom and her boyfriend were going to have a double date with our family friends. Things were great until they left .My brother was in preschool at the time and they gave them these paper books and worksheets to do and I had to help him. I thought ok this will be easy, I had him read the book and my mom told me that he knows the words so I wouldn’t have to sound out every single one. But I had to because he wouldn’t do the work, and the baby wouldn’t quit crying, and the dog wouldn’t stop barking (he hates when babies cry) and the house was crazy! I started to panic. What was I supposed to do? And I didn’t want to ruin my mom's plans and I definitely wanted to prove her wrong. I calmed down and remembered what one of our friends said; he told me to be patient. I let the dog outside and picked up the baby and headed back to the table where my brother was playing. First I read the book aloud; it got both of their attention. Then I told and made a game out of doing the work and it was all good. Then dinner time came. I made some food that we all liked and set the baby in his high chair with his food and gave my brother his plate. I turned around and he threw his plate at me and food was everywhere! I got mad and told myself be patient. I cleaned up the mess and fed the kids and put in a movie and they all fell asleep! I quietly cleaned up the house and my mom and friends walked in and were surprised I did it. Patience is a big part of life; if you lose your temper it just makes things worse, so remaining calm and composed is crucial for navigating difficult situations successfully.

One day my mom came home from work. She came in and said “Son, do you want to go shopping for your clothes now or later?” I chose later. So my mom changed her clothes and we were off to the store. It was around 5:00 PM so it was rush hour. It seemed like it was taking forever and I was getting mad. Then my mom said be patient and it will be over soon. This is a time when I was patient. After ten minutes, things started to clear up. It still took a while but it was getting better. In less than twenty minutes we were pulling up in the Macy’s parking lot. There was a few cars in the lot but it didn’t seem like much. When we got into the store that’s when I really was mad. The lines for you to purchase your items lead all the way to the back of the store. Then my mom said “Now look. The lines are long as you can see. Are you sure you can handle this and have patients?” “I’ll try”. I said. After we got in the store we were looking for my clothes, we were looking at the long lines also, to see if they went down some. We got my clothes, then got in line. We spent about an hour worth of time in the line and it made me mad. Not only did it make me mad, it made me hungry because I skipped lunch. When we got out of the store, we were happy and hungry. We left the store and went to McDonald's. When we were down the street from McDonald's, there was this traffic line we got closer and closer to McDonald's and then realized that line was the McDonald's line. We got in the lot and I knew for sure that I was going to have more patients. So we waited and the line went really fast. When we got our food, the lady said “Thank you for your patients”. Then she asked us would we like a free frie of any size for our wait. We told her yes and we will take a large frie. My mom turn to me and said “Do you see what happens if you be patient?” I said yeah and patients is a good thing to have. That was a time when I was patient.

Fishing is a great sport, but it takes a lot of patience. My first fishing trip was at a lake about 50 miles from my home. I had loved fishing ever since then, but the trip wasn't easy. I think that fishing is fun because I was patient; accomplishing what I did took every ounce of patience I had. When my uncle visits from Chicago he always brings his fishing rods and fishes in a different way. I never went with him until about one year ago. He decided that I should bring a friend, so if I got bored, I would have someone to talk to. The patience started when we were about half way there and BANG! We hit a fence. The car had broken down so we called a tow truck. The wait was about 2 hours, 30 min and my friend asked, "So are we there yet?" My friend sucked. We finally fixed the car and drove the rest of the way. Once we got there, we had two problems to fix, and we had no bait. We found a nice spot at the other side of the lake. We had to scavenge for some bait, which took about 4 hours for enough bait. We were finally ready to fish. We got the rods, sat the chairs, cast, and waited. There was no way to make fishing faster so we sat, hoping for some bites. In the end my uncle, my friend, and I caught 8 fish! We had eat three for lunch and went home with 5 fish left. I love to go fishing because it relaxes me. I felt like anything could have happened, but we went fishing, relaxed, and brought a couple of meals home. That's why I love fishing because it requires patience.

This is a story about patience. Patience is needed in life. Sometimes when you get very frustrated, you need patience. One reason is if someone or something gets you mad, you need patience or you can get in trouble. For example if you get mad because of someone and you start a fight, you’ll get in huge trouble with the law and possibly hurt someone. Or if you try doing something and you can’t, you need patience or you can break something and get in trouble with your parents or others. Another reason for patience is if you are working with someone or teaching someone, you need patience so you don’t hurt their feelings if they can’t do something right, such as a new skill. They might get mad and not want to be with you or learn from you. A third reason for patience is if you know someone who keeps getting you mad or keeps humiliating you, you need to have patience with him/her. Just ignore the person so you both don’t get in trouble at school or work. If you wouldn’t have patience, things could end drastically, with broken relationships or worse. So that is why you should have patience. Without patience you can get in trouble, lose a friend, and a lot of other things could go wrong, making life difficult. That’s why you need patience to navigate challenges and maintain positive relationships.

When I think about patience, I usually think of my mom, and how tolerant and understanding she is. Even when she has explained something to me about 100 times and I still don’t understand, she helps me without complaining. A good example of this is when she and my dad taught me how to ride a bike. My dad had told me that you needed turn the handlebars before you crashed, but I kept forgetting and falling down. Devastated that this wasn’t easy, I gave up a little bit after. Now, though, my mom gently persuaded me to try again. Holding on to the bike, she told me to pedal. She let go, and yelled, “turn! Turn!” but this was no use. I turned the wrong way and toppled over on the grass. “That’s okay. You almost had it!” mom said rushing over to me. Putting on a brave face, I tried again. Over and over, I tried to ride my bike. Not once getting mad at me, mom helped me up. On my one last try before it was time to go back in the house, my mom let go and I rode all by myself, around the corner and back! When I got back, we both did little dances, my mom congratulated me, and we called my dad to brag about my new accomplishment. To me, my mom showed patience that day. She didn’t let me give up and she never complained. Overall, my mom is a perfect example of patience, and because of that, she taught me how to ride a bike!

What is patient? Being patient means to wait for something that can take a long time, but you understand and wait without being rude. An example is waiting for a toy that just came out; everyone has it and it's the coolest toy in town. The problem is your mom and dad can't afford it right now. When you understand that money's tight and you don't start by your mom's side begging for the toy every day, you're being patient, showing understanding and restraint. If you're not doing that, then you're not being patient, and your mom might say, "stop, you're being impatient." Before you're rude and keep begging for what you want, think of other people, understand why it might take longer than you want, and be patient, because patience involves considering others and accepting delays with grace.

In Maplewood middle school, in Mrs. Davison's dirty and muddy science classroom, a boy named John and another named James were cleaning the mess they made earlier, from their mudball fight.
