It was my first game. I was pumped, ready to go in, coach yelled "big guy" and I was by his side, helmet in hand. Then he said next play you're going in. Never went in not once. I was very patient, perhaps too patient. Not to say I wasn’t mad; disappointment simmered beneath the surface. At least I got some exercise standing there, shifting my weight and trying to stay loose. The whole time I supported my teammates, shouting encouragement and offering high fives. I helped in any way shape or form, handing out water and towels. I listened to them complain about missed blocks or tough opponents, but I did give support and positive feedback. There I was, so mad I could have screamed. I was ready, I felt ready, but my coach said no. It was my time to shine, or so I thought. That one stupid word stood in my way: no. But at least I learned something about perseverance and team spirit, even when facing personal disappointment.

Patience is something not very many people have. I am in between, I can be patient at times, BUT at other times I'm not. To be patient is to be understanding and tolerant. It also means you can go through tough times without complaining. Every year I'm not that patient, and every year we go to Mackinac. We go to Mackinac for labor day, to walk the bridge. The rule is, if you don't complain you get fudge. I thought I wasn't gonna get fudge, because I had pulled muscles in both my legs and the night before embers burnt my legs. I knew that to get fudge I had to be patient. So I got dressed, walked to the bridge, and gathered up all my confidence and patience and started the mighty walk. Every year we try and beat our bridge walking time and I thought my legs would slow us down. So I told myself "be patient" over and over and then I sped up going past the first three miles in 40 minutes, (because my legs were worn out). I knew to beat our record we would have to walk two miles in less than twenty minutes. We were walking faster than I thought we could and my legs felt like THEY were ready to burst! I couldn't do it anymore. I knew I had to stop and complain, BUT my legs kept telling me "KEEP GOING!" THEY wouldn't let me stop, THEY were: tolerating the pain and being patient. I also had to be patient if I wanted fudge. So I cranked up the speed and sped to the finish line not only to get fudge, BUT also to beat our record. Thanks to patience I got delicious fudge and we beat our record. That's a time I'll never forget, because I had patience and I kept going until I crossed the finish line. That's how I was patient, and I'm glad I was patient with my legs. I'm not very patient so thank goodness for patience, because it allowed me to achieve something I didn't think I could.

Being patient is all about being tolerant and understanding. Sometimes when I'm in a bad mood I have to be patient when someone asks me a dumb question or gets on my nerves. One day (last year) I was feeling sick and upset it was during vacation and my little sister wanted some ice cream, but not from the ice cream tank that rode by every twenty minutes from the ice-cream shop which was about seven to ten blocks away. I was bundled in my blanket when she jumped on my bed. "I I I I want to go get ice-cream. , , !!!" I said in a mean voice. "You little hobgoblin get off my bed OR I'LL YOU!!!" I was younger and in a terrible mood that crying sound so silly and stupid. Tears came to her eyes and I didn’t realize at that moment that she was little (four years old) and didn’t quite understand that I didn’t feel good. I apologized and explained that I was sick. Immediately after she ran out of the room and ten minutes later came back with a hot cup of tea and said "I made mama make you some tea". That was heart warming to me. After I drank it she asked if I felt better. I said a little then she got on my bed and started bouncing. I was patient with her and knew that she didn’t fully understand yet. So I got up and took her to the ice-cream shop to get some ice-cream. She was happy and that made me happy. I felt extremely proud that I was patient with her even when she got on me nerves. I know I wasn’t patient with her at the "beginning" but at the end I was, and that small act of patience created a more positive outcome for both of us.

I am going to write a story about patience. Patience is when you wait for somebody to do something. One example of this might be if someone else is fixing something for you and you really want them to be finished so you can move on with your life, but it is the type of thing that takes time, maybe a lot of time, but if you want it done right, you will have to wait. Sometimes it will not be a person you wait for, but an inanimate object, like a television show, which can not be rushed, even though sometimes you want to rush it. With a human however, if you rush them to do something, it might end up being not as good and even breaking in about ten seconds after them doing it, but it might end up happening faster though. You might also wait for nature too, such as a sunny day, when it might have been raining for over a week. You also might be waiting for the power to come back on during a storm. I, for me, have really wanted the power to come back on during a storm because there is nothing to do! Patience is also about waiting for your boredom to pass, like when you are just stuck inside and there is nothing to do. It is hard to wait in moments like those, but it is a necessary skill to practice. So, patience involves waiting in many different situations, and practicing it is ultimately important.

ìDid it come yet!?î I yelled, sprinting home from the bus stop. She was standing by the mailbox, holding a thick wad of envelopes. One of these, I hoped, was the letter. ìNot yet honey,î she said ìbut thereís plenty of bills to go around.î I wanted to scream in exasperation, but I remembered what Mom said, ìjust wait long enough and youíll get what you want.î I trudged inside and plopped down on the couch. This letter meant so much to me. It said which advanced classes I would be in. It doesnít sound that important, but only the elite could get in, and this meant the world to me. I would be challenged, my parents would be so proud of me, and I would get 50 bucks from grandma. See, you take a test at the end of school and wait the entire summer for results. Pretty good system, huh? No! Pretty soon, other things distracted me: swim meets, tennis, books, and I learned that it helps to be patient, and time goes by a lot faster. Mom was right, I guess. One August afternoon at 3:00 PM, on the last day of summer, I was on the porch reading. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw the mailman. He shuffled around in his bag, and pulled out mail, put it in our mailbox and drove away. I leaped out of my chair and ran to the mailbox. I surveyed the mail quickly, until one envelope caught my eye. I ripped it open and sure enough, it read "Sarah has been selected for the following advanced classes: AP English, AP History, AP Biology!" My patience finally paid off, and I realized that sometimes waiting really does make the reward even sweeter.

Patience is tough to achieve sometimes. But that doesn't mean you should give up, keep trying and you will succeed; rush through life and become impatient and you used and succed. I will tell you a popular virtue story to explain patience. Every year in the fall a big race takes place. All the animals in the forest come to see it. It is an extraordinary event. It is a tradition that every year, one slow animal and one fast animal compete to see who is this year's champion. At the time the rabbit was the fastest animal around. The rabbit signed up every year and won every time. The tortoise had signed up to compete this year. The rabbit was very confident in himself and was full of pride because the rabbit was fast, slow and the rabbit can't be a champion. "Runners get ready!" shouted the announcer. The rabbit and tortoise lined up. "Ready, Set, Go!!" The rabbit rushed ahead kicking the air. For the tortoise very slowly waiting behind. Rabbit run like he has never won. He never looked back. He wanted to win. The trophy was rightfully his anyways. Right? I mean, he was the fastest animal. Tortoise continued on his way, slowly but surely making his way to the finish line. "Hmm, Hmm." Rabbit stopped and looked around. No one was around. "What is that noise?" he asked aloud. "Hmm" it came from his stomach he was so caught up in the race he didn't realize how hungry he was. "Just one little handful of berries." he decided. He picked a handful, then another and another. Finally he was full and a little bit sleepy. "I'll just take a little nap after all that tortoise ain't gonna catch up anyways." He laid down and slept. Little did rabbit know that the whole time he was eating and napping, tortoise was catching up? He saw the rabbit sleeping and decided not to wake him just in case he was sick and he continued to slowly very slowly walk up the hill to the finish line. Rabbit woke to the sound or cheering. He stood up. The tortoise won! He raced to the finish line but was too late, the tortoise had already won. If he had been patient he might have won. The story shows that patience, even when difficult, is essential for achieving goals, as rushing and impatience can lead to failure.

I think that patience is about waiting instead of rushing things. Be patient with whatever you're doing, even if you are waiting for a turn; just wait, it is not a big deal. Stop rushing things; just be very patient, and you will find things often work out for the best when you don't try to force them.

There are two reasons why I think patience is important. The first is because if you are not patient, than you can end up distracting other people around you. For example, if you finished your test early and you kept telling everyone else to hurry up it’s distracting. Now that you’ve interrupted everyone, they have lost their train of thought and now they have to start over. A few weeks ago, my sister and I were out walking my dog and he pulled so hard my little sister fell over and my dog ran away. We had to be patient and wait for him to return. My sister kept wanting to go call my mom to tell her the dog ran away again but I told her it would be rude to call because it would distract her from her work. Another reason why patience is important is because if you are not patient you can get hurt. Let’s say you were going down the stairs and your sibling was in front of you and you needed to get downstairs quickly but they were walking down the stairs very slow, so you pushed them, they could get very hurt. For example, they could fall and break an arm. In conclusion, patience is needed always and cannot be forgotten.

As we walked in the smell of mouth wash filled our noses, we walked to the front desk. A short little lady with knotty hair and glasses greeted us. "Take a seat in our waiting room and your dentist will be with you shortly," the lady at the desk said. We walked to the waiting room. My mom and brother sat on the waiting couch, and I sat in the little tan chair in the corner. My brother got some papers and crayons while my mom and I waited. But I was wrong; fifteen minutes went by. My mom and my brother were still doing the same thing, while I was looking around the room, bored out of my mind. I kept asking my mom when the dentist would come, but she just told me to be patient. About twenty minutes later, I was starting to lose it. I could no longer sit still. I did not know how my brother could just sit there and color for twenty minutes. I wanted to ask my mom when the dentist was going to come, but she would just tell me to be patient. I got up and started pacing back and forth. After five minutes of that, my mom told me to sit down and find something to do. But there was nothing, nothing I could possibly do that could entertain me. Finally, when I was about to go crazy, a little lady stood in the doorway. "Time for your appointment," she said. Being patient is waiting quietly for something to happen. A lot of times, you have to patient for a lot of things, such as long lectures, birthdays, and orchestra concerts. Sometimes, no matter how patient you are, the thing you have been waiting for does not happen, and you'd have to leave without doing what you wanted to do for the whole time (and that has happened many times with me). For long lectures, sometimes you have the urge to leave. You have to be patient and wait for the lecture to end. For birthdays, you really want to eat the cake. But, yes, you do have to wait until your annoying sister finishes blowing out the candles and makes her wish. I am part of the orchestra, and we have a orchestra concert about every two months. The first concert is an open concert, and they are usually in May. Last year it was the spring concert. At the end of the concert, there is a cheese cake sampling station, and cookies, and donuts, and all these good cake. But first, I must suffer through playing through many pieces, watch the beginners play and watching at honid video ??? videotapes my face, waiting for a mistake so any annoying can laugh at it and call me an "epicfail". But I still live. Playing the piece isn't so bad, it's just some pieces of paper with notes and watching the beginners might is torture, but at least I don't have to play. Video taping? No pain at all. Who says I'm going to mess up? All I have to do is to sit in the back row, and my mom might not even see me. My sisters might not even care. And then soon comes the cheese cake, at like 9:30 at night. That is the good part, but to get to the good part, I must be patient. I'm not really looking forward to this year's concert, on May 12th, because on that day I have a final cross-country meet after school. Where all five middle schools come together for a big district meet at a place called Central Park Middle School. After that meet, my parents have to bring me to that concert at the high school at 7:30 PM. The concert closes down at 11, like always, and I am hoping I'm not going to get any homework. But if I do, I'll just have to be patient. That day is like any old day. Long. I'll have to wait until school ends, the meet ends, and the concert ends to go home, but I can live. All that is on my mind is to live the whole school year, patiently, without messing up or failing badly, and knowing that patience, even when tested, will eventually lead to the cheesecake.

"Mom!" Jenny whined, her voice escalating into a wail. "You can’t do this to me. I’m ten!" "Jenny, calm down. I know you are ten, and at that, a very responsive ten year old. Honey I have told you before, I can’t leave you at the house all day. Your father and I have work honey!" "Mom can’t you just hire a babysitter? What about Susan? She babysitted last year!" Jenny’s mother sighed. "I know you liked Susan, but Susan just wasn’t fit to the requirements I was looking for. Besides, you said you wanted to be a babysitter! Why not try and help at the center?" Jenny used her well practiced glare at her mother that said "if!". This conversation had been held two weeks ago in the kitchen of the Fullers. Mary, Jenny’s mother, Mrs. Fuller, was taking her to Maple county’s only day care, Sunshine and Rainbows Daycare. The name made Jenny want to gag. "Mary remember sweetie, be nice and try to help out a bit. I love you!" Mary called as she started to pull out of the driveway. Jenny turned to face the small building. The sign above the building stated "Sunshine and Rainbows Daycare. A friendly and loving environment" Jenny had that gagging feeling again. Jenny turned back to see if she could spot her mother’s red, battered, Toyota speeding down the poorly paved road. But all she saw was a trail of dust. Great, Jenny thought as she entered through the double doors that had a picture of a big, grinning, clown, "Jenny, why don’t you play with little Timmy?" Mrs. Davis said, comforting "little" Timmy in her arms, actually, Timmy was seven, which Jenny thought was a big enough age to not cry when someone yells at them when they’ve asked to play "one" for the billionth time. "Jenny we need to talk." Mrs. Davis the middle aged woman, shunning Timmy to the side, " honey, you’ve got to understand that kids need patience and love. Heck, I remember you as a kid! Boy were you an attention hog!" Jenny looked like she regretted yelling. She smiled and went to find Timmy. Maybe he’d still be game for you, and perhaps Jenny could find some way to tolerate her time at Sunshine and Rainbows.

A time I was patient was when I was at a dentist office I had to get six teeth pulled. When we were waiting I kept asking my mom "when are we going, when are we going?" When they said my name I walked into the room. I asked if it was going to hurt and they said, "you won't feel a thing." The doctor put a tube on my mouth and said, "close your eyes and breathe." Without even knowing it, I fell asleep from the gas. I was asleep for two hours, and when I wanted to get out of the chair, they said "no, no, no," so I sat and sat until five minutes later they let me out. I was all loopy and had to be put in a wheelchair. When I got to the front desk they let me take two toys, and my mom gave me a wrestler. When we were about to leave, my mom talked to the doctor, and they took forever. When we got in the car, my mom took the wheelchair back, and we were off. During the ride, my mom told me I couldn't go to school that day because of my teeth. She said not to look in the mirror, but I did, and it was gross. I had to wait three hours for food and drinks, so I was thirsty. When she said I could eat, I was happy. I am still patient because the doctor said that grown-up teeth would come in a few months, but it has been two years and nothing, so I am disappointed, but now I have to be patient and wait for my mom to take me to get braces, which is gonna hurt really bad, requiring even more patience in the future.

I hate weddings. I love when people get married, but I hate the ceremonies. They’re so boring. Especially the long weddings that take like two hours of people just standing there or doing nothing. I’m not the most patient person, so that’s probably why I hate long weddings. Now that is one long story about patience. “Do we have to go?” I moaned to my mother. “Sweetie, it’s Sarah’s wedding and it’s important.” “Ugh.” I had to surrender as I put on my new dress and got in the car. The wedding was all the way in Riverside. It usually takes only an hour to get there, but not this time. Our family was about a quarter of the way there when we got into a major traffic jam. “Come on!” my sister yelled. I just kept quiet. Finally, when the traffic jam cleared up, a dramatic event just shot out. The road we had to go down was closed. So much for taking the short way. We had just entered the town next to Riverside when we got a call from my grandma. “Hello?” My mom answered. “Where are you? The ceremony just ended,” “Oh no. That’s bad. We’re in Hilldale, why? Has the reception started yet?” “Not yet, but I’m sure you’ll make it in time to be there,” “Okay. That’s good. Bye.” “Bye.” Miraculously, as if on cue, we reached the reception. I was so happy to be there even if I do hate weddings. “Did you have fun?” My mom asked as we arrived home. “Fun? I asked.” “Actually, I guess I did, even the car ride was kind of fun.” “Really? You tend not to be the patient type.” “I know” I said and I was proud. It seems that even I can learn to tolerate things, and maybe even find the slightest bit of enjoyment, when it matters to the people I care about.
